recipe1.title: Chicken chow mein dinner bowl
recipe1.ingredients: 350g packet fresh chow mein noodles 2 teaspoons sesame oil 2 1/2 cups finely shredded red cabbage 1 baby pak choy, thinly sliced crossways 227g can sliced water chestnuts, drained, thinly sliced 1 tablespoon vegetable oil 500g chicken breast stir-fry strips 3 garlic cloves, crushed 1/4 cup oyster sauce 2 tablespoons soy sauce 2 tablespoons shao hsing (Chinese rice wine) 1/4 teaspoon ground white pepper 2 carrots, cut into matchsticks 1/2 cup bean sprouts, trimmed 3 green onions, thinly sliced 2 teaspoons sesame seeds, toasted 1 sliced long red chilli, to serve
recipe1.instructions: Step 1 Cook noodles following packet directions. Drain. Place in a bowl. Add 1/2 the sesame oil. Toss to combine. Step 2 Meanwhile, combine cabbage, pak choy and water chestnuts in a bowl. Step 3 Heat vegetable oil and remaining sesame oil in a wok or large frying pan. Stir-fry chicken for 5 minutes or until browned. Add garlic, sauces, shao hsing and pepper. Stir-fry for 2 minutes or until chicken is cooked through and sauce mixture thickens slightly. Step 4 Arrange noodles, cabbage mixture, chicken mixture and carrot in serving bowls. Top with bean sprouts, green onion, sesame seeds and chilli. Serve.

recipe2.title: Sticky Chinese barbecue lamb
recipe2.ingredients: 1/3 cup (95g) hoisin sauce 2 tablespoons soy sauce 1 teaspoon Chinese five spice 3 garlic cloves, crushed 1 tablespoon ginger, finely grated 2.6kg Coles Australian Lamb Whole Leg Roast 2 brown onions, quartered 1/2 cup coriander sprigs Steamed jasmine rice, to serve Steamed Chinese broccoli, to serve Sliced red chilli, to serve
recipe2.instructions: Step 1 Preheat a covered barbecue on medium. Alternatively, preheat oven to 200C. Step 2 Combine hoisin sauce, soy sauce, Chinese five spice, garlic, ginger and 2 tablespoons of water in a jug. Score lamb at 1cm intervals. Rub half the mixture all over lamb. Place onion in a disposable baking dish. Top with lamb. Cover with foil. Bake in covered barbecue using indirect heat, or in oven, for 2 hours 30 mins, brushing with remaining hoisin mixture every 15 mins for the last hour, for medium or until cooked to your liking. Step 3 Transfer lamb to a plate and cover with foil. Set aside for 20 mins to rest. Top lamb with coriander. Serve with rice, broccoli and chilli.

recipe3.title: Mr Shum's dumplings
recipe3.ingredients: 1/4 teaspoon ground white pepper 2 teaspoons shao hsing (Chinese cooking wine) 1 teaspoon sesame oil 5g chicken stock cube, crumbled 1 teaspoon caster sugar 1 teaspoon salt 1 garlic clove, crushed 350g pork mince 1 cup shredded wombok (Chinese cabbage) 1/2 brown onion, finely chopped 1 small celery stalk, finely chopped 30 gow gee wrappers 1/4 cup peanut oil Seasoned red vinegar, to serve Finely shredded fresh ginger, to serve
recipe3.instructions: Step 1 Place pepper, wine, sesame oil, stock cube, sugar, salt and garlic in a bowl. Using a fork, mash until a smooth paste forms. Add mince, wombok, onion and celery. Mix for 5 minutes or until mixture is combined and sticky. Step 2 Place 1 gow gee wrapper on a flat surface. Spoon 2 level teaspoons of pork mixture into centre of wrapper. Brush edges with cold water. Press edges together to seal, then pleat. Place on a baking paper-lined baking tray. Cover with a clean tea towel. Repeat with remaining wrappers and pork mixture, placing dumplings in a single layer on tray. Step 3 Preheat oven to 150°C/130°C fan-forced. Line a large baking tray with baking paper. Heat 1 tablespoon peanut oil in a large non-stick frying pan over medium heat. Add 10 dumplings. Cook for 2 minutes or until bases are golden brown. Gently pour over 1/2 cup hot water. Cover. Cook for a further 5 minutes or until water evaporates and dumplings are cooked through. Transfer to the prepared baking tray. Cover loosely with foil. Place in an oven to keep warm. Step 4 Repeat, in 2 batches, with remaining oil and dumplings. Serve immediately with combined vinegar and ginger.
